com.apriori.concurrent.scheduler

Class ScheduledTaskManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.concurrent.scheduler.ScheduledTaskManager
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ListenableExecutorService, ListenableScheduledExecutorService, java.util.concurrent.Executor, java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService, java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService

    public class ScheduledTaskManager
extends java.lang.Object
implements ListenableScheduledExecutorService
    An extension and enhancement to the API provided by ScheduledExecutorService.

    This implementation provides greater configurability over scheduled tasks and greater optics into the results of executions of the tasks. It is API-compatible with the standard ScheduledExecutorService, so it should behave the same if using only the standard API and not any of the extensions herein.

    Key Interfaces

    TaskDefinition
    The definition of a scheduled task. This defines when a task runs, if it is repeated and how often, what actual code is executed when the task is run, etc.
    ScheduledTaskDefinition
    A TaskDefinition that has been scheduled for execution with a ScheduledTaskManager. This provides additional API for inspecting the status of task invocations and controlling the task, like pausing/suspending executions and canceling the task.
    ScheduledTask
    A single invocation of a ScheduledTaskDefinition. If the task is defined as a repeating task, there will be multiple such invocations of this task over time. This interface is also a ScheduledFuture and is returned when submitting scheduled tasks to the executor service.
    RepeatingScheduledTask
    Represents all invocations of a repeating ScheduledTaskDefinition. This is for API and behavioral compatibility with the ScheduledFutures returned by the standard ScheduledExecutorService.scheduleAtFixedRate(Runnable, long, long, TimeUnit) and ScheduledExecutorService.scheduleWithFixedDelay(Runnable, long, long, TimeUnit) methods.

    Client code uses a TaskDefinition.Builder to construct a task and define all of the parameters for its execution. It is then scheduled with the ScheduledTaskManager for execution.

    Features

    The main features in this service, not available with the standard scheduled executor API, follow:

    • Asynchronous processing using FutureListeners. All of the futures returned by this service are instances of ListenableFuture, which has a broader and more usable API than the standard Future, including the ability to add listeners to process results asynchronously.
    • Greater control over repeated occurrences and how they are scheduled. Instead of a task either always repeating (unless an invocation fails) or never repeating (unless the logic itself schedules a successor when invoked), tasks specify a ScheduleNextTaskPolicy. Also, tasks specify a Rescheduler, which provides greater flexibility over the timing of subsequent tasks. Rescheduler implementations are provided for simple fixed-rate and fixed-delay schedules.
    • Notification of individual invocations. For repeated tasks, instead of only being able to wait for all invocations to finish (which generally only happens after an invocation fails) or cancel all subsequent invocations, this API provides granularity at individual task level. You can listen for completions of any and all invocations. You can also cancel individual invocations of a task.
    • Greater job control. As mentioned above, you can cancel individual occurrences of a task instead of canceling the entire job. You can also pause execution of a task temporarily. This does not attempt to suspend any thread currently executing the task, but simply stops scheduling future instances of the job until the task is resumed.
    • Exception handling. You can specify an Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler for each task to handle job failures. This, combined with a ScheduleNextTaskPolicy, provides much more flexibility in handling exceptions thrown by task invocations.
    • Job History. In addition to listening for task completions, you can access the results of recent invocations for a repeated task - the task's history.

                                     long delay,

        Schedules the specified task for execution. If the specified delay is zero or negative, it is scheduled for immediate execution. The returned object will not only be a listenable future, it will be a ScheduledTask.

      • scheduleAtFixedRate

        public <V> RepeatingScheduledTask<V> scheduleAtFixedRate(java.util.concurrent.Callable<V> task,
                                                         long initialDelay,
                                                         long period,
                                                         java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
        Schedules the specified task for periodic execution. If the specified initial delay is zero or negative, it is scheduled for immediate execution. The task will execute at a fixed rate per the specified period, but never more than a single instance will be executing at a given time. Instead of running tasks concurrently, if a single occurrence takes longer than the period, subsequent instances will be delayed and be scheduled to start as soon as the slow occurrence completes.

        This is very similar to scheduleAtFixedRate(Runnable, long, long, TimeUnit), which is API provided by ScheduledExecutorService. But this version can run a callable that produces a value. The returned future has additional methods for inspecting the results produced by past executions.

        Parameters:
        task - the task to execute
        initialDelay - the delay from submission time when the first occurrence should execute
        period - the period of time between occurrences
        unit - the unit for initialDelay and period
        Returns:
        a listenable scheduled future that can be used to inspect the task's state and past results
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if task or unit is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if period is non-positive
        See Also:
        scheduleAtFixedRate(Runnable, long, long, TimeUnit)

      • scheduleAtFixedRate

        public RepeatingScheduledTask<java.lang.Void> scheduleAtFixedRate(java.lang.Runnable task,
                                                                  long initialDelay,
                                                                  long period,
                                                                  java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
        Description copied from interface: ListenableScheduledExecutorService

      • scheduleWithFixedDelay

        public <V> RepeatingScheduledTask<V> scheduleWithFixedDelay(java.util.concurrent.Callable<V> task,
                                                            long initialDelay,
                                                            long delay,
                                                            java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
        Schedules the specified task for repeated execution. If the specified initial delay is zero or negative, it is scheduled for immediate execution. The task will execute with a fixed delay between invocations.

        This is very similar to scheduleWithFixedDelay(Runnable, long, long, TimeUnit), which is API provided by ScheduledExecutorService. But this version can run a callable that produces a value. The returned future has additional methods for inspecting the results produced by past executions.

        Parameters:
        task - the task to execute
        initialDelay - the delay from submission time when the first occurrence should execute
        delay - the delay between occurrences
        unit - the unit for initialDelay and delay
        Returns:
        a listenable scheduled future that can be used to inspect the task's state and past results
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if task or unit is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if delay is non-positive
        See Also:
        scheduleWithFixedDelay(Runnable, long, long, TimeUnit)

      • submit

        public <V> ScheduledTask<V> submit(java.util.concurrent.Callable<V> task)

        Overrides the return type to be listenable.

        This implementation is the same as using the schedule(Callable, long, TimeUnit) method but indicating a zero delay so the task is scheduled for immediate execution. The returned future is not just a listenable future, but is a ScheduledTask.

        Specified by:
        submit in interface ListenableExecutorService
        Specified by:
        submit in interface java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService

      • submit

        public <V> ScheduledTask<V> submit(java.lang.Runnable task,
                                   V result)

        Overrides the return type to be listenable.

        This implementation is similar to using the schedule(Runnable, long, TimeUnit) method with a zero delay so the task is scheduled for immediate execution. The key difference being that this form allows a non-null value to be used as the result. The returned future is not just a listenable future, but is a ScheduledTask.

        Specified by:
        submit in interface ListenableExecutorService
        Specified by:
        submit in interface java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService

      • schedule

        public <V> ScheduledTaskDefinition<V> schedule(TaskDefinition<V> taskDef)
        Schedules the specified task definition for execution. On return, the first occurrence of the task (or only occurrence if not a repeating task) will be scheduled.
        Parameters:
        taskDef - the definition of the task to schedule
        Returns:
        the scheduled form of the task definition
